option.value: {"/Users/nchinnabattini/Desktop/JavaFundamentals":"{\"/CombinationOfTablesJavaTask/src/models/Faculty.java\":\"This file does not contain any classes, but it does have the following functions:\\n\\n`main`: This function creates a data table of faculty information and prints it to the console.\\n\\n`FacultyTable`: This function creates a 2D list of faculty information, including the faculty ID, name, and subject.\\n\\n`printDataTable`: This function takes a 2D list of data and prints it to the console in a tabular format.\\n\\nOverall, this file is a simple program that creates and prints a table of faculty information.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/GettingStarted/DiceGame/Maintain.java\":\"This file does not contain any classes or functions. Instead, it is a Java program that calculates the Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR) for a person based on their weight, height, and age, and then determines the number of calories they would need to consume to maintain their weight, given the calorie content of a specific food item.\\n\\nThe program prompts the user to enter the person\\u0027s weight in pounds, height in inches, age in years, and the name and calorie content of a food item. It then calculates the BMR for both men and women using the Mifflin-St Jeor equation, and then determines the number of units of the food item that the person would need to consume to maintain their weight.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/GettingStarted/LoopingAndArrays/doWhileLoop.java\":\"This file does not contain any classes or functions. Instead, it demonstrates the use of a `do-while` loop in Java. The program initializes an integer variable `ival` with the value `80`, and then enters a `do-while` loop that prints the value of `ival`, multiplies it by 2, and prints the result. The loop continues until the value of `ival` becomes less than `25`.\",\"/CombinationOfTablesJavaTask/src/models/Student.java\":\"This file defines a `Student` class with the following members:\\n\\n`Student`: A class that represents a student with an ID, name, gender, and semester.\\n\\n`toString()`: A method that returns a string representation of the `Student` object.\\n\\n`Student()`: A default constructor for the `Student` class.\\n\\n`Student(int, String, String, String)`: A constructor that initializes the `Student` object with the provided ID, name, gender, and semester.\\n\\n`getId()`: A method that returns the ID of the `Student` object.\\n\\n`setId(int)`: A method that sets the ID of the `Student` object.\\n\\n`getName()`: A method that returns the name of the `Student` object.\\n\\n`setName(String)`: A method that sets the name of the `Student` object.\\n\\n`getGender()`: A method that returns the gender of the `Student` object.\\n\\n`setGender(String)`: A method that sets the gender of the `Student` object.\\n\\n`getSem()`: A method that returns the semester of the `Student` object.\\n\\n`setSem(String)`: A method that sets the semester of the `Student` object.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/GettingStarted/DiceGame/StudentQuestion.java\":\"This file does not contain any classes or functions. Instead, it is a Java program that calculates a student\\u0027s final grade based on their exam and homework scores, and provides the score required on the final exam to achieve different letter grades.\\n\\nThe program prompts the user to enter their scores for Exam 1, Exam 2, and the average homework score. It then calculates the student\\u0027s current grade based on the weighted scores, and determines the score required on the final exam to achieve different letter grades (A, B, C, D, and F). Finally, it prints the results to the console.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/GettingStarted/palindrome.java\":\"This file contains a single class `palindrome` that checks if a given string is a palindrome or not.\\n\\n`palindrome`: This class checks if a given string is a palindrome or not.\\n\\n`main`: This function takes a string input from the user, reverses it, and compares it with the original string to determine if it is a palindrome or not.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/ScalerTopicsJava/Loops/WhileExample1.java\":\"This file contains a single class `WhileExample1` that demonstrates the use of the `while` loop in Java to calculate the factorial of a given number.\\n\\n`WhileExample1`: This class demonstrates the use of the `while` loop to calculate the factorial of a given number.\\n\\n`main(String[] args)`: This function takes user input for a number, calculates its factorial using a `while` loop, and prints the result.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/GettingStarted/prefixAndPostfix.java\":\"This file does not contain any classes. It contains the following functions:\\n\\n`main`: This function demonstrates the usage of prefix and postfix increment/decrement operators, as well as compound assignment operations in Java.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/GettingStarted/LoopingAndArrays/forLoop.java\":\"This file does not contain any classes or functions. Instead, it demonstrates the use of a `for` loop in Java to print the powers of 2 up to 100.\\n\\nThe program starts by defining a `main` method, which is the entry point of the Java application. Inside the `main` method, a `for` loop is used to iterate from 1 to 100, with the loop variable `i` being multiplied by 2 in each iteration. The value of `i` is then printed to the console.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/GettingStarted/DiceGame/DiceHILO.java\":\"This file contains a single class `DiceHILO` and several functions within it. The file implements a simple dice game called \\\"Hi-Lo\\\" where the user tries to guess whether the next roll of a dice will be higher or lower than the previous roll.\\n\\n`DiceHILO`: The main class that manages the game logic and user interaction.\\n\\n`get_UserName()`: Prompts the user to enter their username.\\n`file_Exists(String username)`: Checks if a file exists for the given username.\\n`read_User_Data()`: Reads the user\\u0027s previous game data from a file.\\n`start_the_Game()`: Runs the main game loop, allowing the user to play the Hi-Lo game.\\n`roll_the_Dice()`: Generates a random number between 1 and 6 to simulate a dice roll.\\n`game_Prediction(String guess, int lastRoll, int nextRoll)`: Determines if the user\\u0027s guess (higher or lower) is correct based on the last and next dice rolls.\\n`save_User_Data()`: Saves the user\\u0027s game data (successful tries and total tries) to a file.\\n`show_the_Result()`: Displays the user\\u0027s game results, including the success ratio.\\n`main(String[] args)`: The entry point of the program, which orchestrates the game flow.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/GettingStarted/LoopingAndArrays/calcEngineUsingArrays.java\":\"This file does not contain any classes or functions. Instead, it is a Java program that performs various arithmetic operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division) on arrays of left and right values, using an array of operation codes. The program then prints the results of these operations.\\n\\nThe main functionality of this file can be summarized as follows:\\n\\nThis Java program demonstrates the use of arrays to perform basic arithmetic operations on a set of left and right values, using an array of operation codes. The program iterates through the operation codes, performs the corresponding arithmetic operation on the corresponding left and right values, and stores the results in an array. Finally, it prints out all the results.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/ScalerTopicsJava/Loops/ForLoop.java\":\"This file contains a single class `ForLoop` and a single function `main()`.\\n\\n`ForLoop`: This class contains the main logic for the program.\\n\\n`main()`: This function takes user input for the maximum number, and then prints all the numbers from 1 to the maximum number using a `for` loop.\\n\\nIn summary, this file is a simple Java program that takes user input for a maximum number and then prints all the numbers from 1 to the maximum number using a `for` loop.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/GettingStarted/ConditionalLogicAndBlockStatements/conditionalVsLogical.java\":\"This file does not contain any classes or functions. Instead, it contains a single `main()` method that demonstrates the use of conditional and logical operators in Java.\\n\\nThe program checks the number of rooms and students, and then prints out a message based on the following conditions:\\n\\n1. If there are rooms available and the number of students per room is greater than 30, it prints \\\"Crowded\\\".\\n2. If there are no rooms available and the number of students is greater than 30, it prints \\\"Rooms not Available\\\".\\n3. If there are no rooms and no students, it prints \\\"No rooms and students are available\\\".\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/random.java\":\"This file does not contain any classes or functions. Instead, it demonstrates the use of labeled `continue` statements in nested loops.\\n\\nThe program has a nested loop structure, where the outer loop iterates twice, and the inner loop iterates up to 6 times. The program uses labeled `continue` statements to skip specific iterations of the inner and outer loops.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/GettingStarted/UnderstandingMethods/something.java\":\"This file does not contain any classes. Score)`: Constructor that initializes the student\\u0027s attributes.\\n\\nThe `main` function demonstrates the use of the `equals()` and `\\u003d\\u003d` operators to compare objects of the for each year.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/GettingStarted/DiceGame/test.java\":\"This file does not contain any classes. It contains the following functions:\\n\\n`main`: The `main` function is the entry point of the program, where it initializes variables `x` and `y`, and then calls the `sentence` function with these variables as arguments.\\n\\n`sentence`: The `sentence` function takes two integer parameters `x` and `y`, and prints them to the console.\\n\\nThe file appears to be a simple program that demonstrates the use of variables and function calls in Java.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/GettingStarted/UnderstandingMethods/calcEngineMethod.java\":\"This file contains a single class `calcEngineMethod` and two functions `main` and `execute`.\\n\\n`calcEngineMethod`: This class contains the main logic for performing arithmetic operations on a set of input values.\\n\\n`main`: This function is the entry point of the program, it initializes the input values, calls the `execute` function to perform the arithmetic operations, and prints the results.\\n\\n`execute`: This function takes an operation code and two operands, performs the corresponding arithmetic operation, and returns the result.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/GettingStarted/ArrayListSort.java\":\"This file contains a single class `ArrayListSort` and two `main()` methods.\\n\\n`ArrayListSort`: This class demonstrates the sorting of an `ArrayList` of integers using the `Collections.sort()` method.\\n\\n`main()`: The first `main()` method generates a list of 100 random integers, sorts the list using `Collections.sort()`, and prints the sorted list.\\n\\nThe second `main()` method demonstrates the sorting of an array of integers using the `Arrays.sort()` method and prints the sorted array.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/GettingStarted/ConditionalLogicAndBlockStatements/conditionalLogicStatements.java\":\"This file does not contain any classes or functions. Instead, it demonstrates the use of conditional logic statements in Java, such as the ternary operator and the `if-else` statement.\\n\\nThe file performs the following tasks:\\n\\n1. Declares two integer variables `value1` and `value2`.\\n2. Compares the values of `value1` and `value2` using the ternary operator and stores the maximum value in the `maxValue` variable.\\n3. Prints the value of `maxValue`.\\n4. Demonstrates the use of an `if-else` chain to compare the values of `value1` and `value2` and print the appropriate message.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/GettingStarted/UnderstandingMethods/Interest.java\":\"`Interest`: This class calculates the interest on a given amount, rate, and number of years.\\n\\n`CalculateInterest`: This function calculates the interest on a given amount, rate, and number of years and returns the result.\\n\\nThe file demonstrates how to define a static method in Java that calculates the interest on a given amount, rate, and number of years, and then calls this method from the `main` function to print the result.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/GettingStarted/Helloworld.java\":\"This file does not contain any classes or functions. It is a simple Java program that prints \\\"Hello Nithin!\\\", \\\"Nice to meet you\\\", \\\"How are you?\\\", and a random number using the `Math.random()` function.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/Main.java\":\"This file contains a single class and a single function:\\n\\n`Main`: This class is the main entry point of the program, where the execution begins.\\n\\n`main(String[] args)`: This function is the starting point of the program, which prints the message \\\"Hello world!\\\" to the console.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/ScalerTopicsJava/WrapperClasses/WrapperClass.java\":\"This file does not contain any classes or functions. Instead, it demonstrates the use of wrapper classes in Java, which are used to convert primitive data types into objects and vice versa.\\n\\nThe file creates primitive data types `int` and `double`, converts them into their corresponding wrapper objects `Integer` and `Double`, and then converts the wrapper objects back into primitive data types. It also checks the type of the wrapper objects using the `instanceof` operator.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/GettingStarted/Variables.java\":\"This file does not contain any classes or functions. Instead, it demonstrates the declaration and usage of various data types in Java, including integers, floating-point numbers, and characters.\\n\\nThe file showcases the following:\\n\\n1. Declaring and initializing integer variables.\\n2. Declaring and initializing final variables (constants).\\n3. Declaring and initializing floating-point variables (float and double).\\n4. Declaring and printing character variables, including a character with an accent.\\n\\nThe purpose of this file is to provide a basic introduction to variable declaration and usage in Java, covering different data types and their respective syntax.\",\"/CombinationOfTablesJavaTask/src/models/Course.java\":\"This file defines a `Course` class with the following:\\n\\n`Course`: A class that represents a course with an ID, name, and semester.\\n\\n`toString()`: A method that returns a string representation of the `Course` object.\\n\\n`Course()`: A default constructor for the `Course` class.\\n\\n`Course(int, String, String)`: A constructor that initializes the `Course` object with the given ID, name, and semester.\\n\\n`getId()`: A method that returns the ID of the `Course` object.\\n\\n`setId(int)`: A method that sets the ID of the `Course` object.\\n\\n`getName()`: A method that returns the name of the `Course` object.\\n\\n`setName(String)`: A method that sets the name of the `Course` object.\\n\\n`getSemister()`: A method that returns the semester of the `Course` object.\\n\\n`setSemister(String)`: A method that sets the semester of the `Course` object.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/ScalerTopicsJava/Loops/ForMatrix.java\":\"This file does not contain any classes or functions. Instead, it is a Java program that creates a 2D matrix of integers and prints it to the console.\\n\\nThe program first takes input from the user for the number of rows and columns in the matrix. It then initializes a 2D array with the specified dimensions and fills it with consecutive integers starting from 1. Finally, it prints the contents of the matrix to the console, with each row on a new line.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/GettingStarted/LoopingAndArrays/arrays.java\":\"This file does not contain any classes or functions. Instead, it demonstrates the usage of arrays in Java. The code creates an array of float values, calculates the sum of the array elements, and prints the intermediate and final results.\\n\\nThe file demonstrates the following:\\n1. Declaring an array of float values using two different methods.\\n2. Iterating through the array using a for loop and adding the values to a sum variable.\\n3. Printing the intermediate and final sum of the array elements.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/GettingStarted/ConditionalLogicAndBlockStatements/calcEngine.java\":\"This file does not contain any classes. It contains the following functions:\\n\\n`main`: This function is the entry point of the program, which performs basic arithmetic operations based on the user-provided operation code and displays the result.\\n\\nThe file is a simple calculator program that allows the user to perform addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division operations on two hardcoded values. The program uses both `if-else` statements and a `switch` statement to handle the different operation codes.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/GettingStarted/ConditionalLogicAndBlockStatements/blockStatements.java\":\"This file does not contain any classes or functions. Instead, it demonstrates the use of block statements and conditional logic in Java.\\n\\nThe code compares two integer variables `v1` and `v2`, and calculates the difference between them. Depending on the comparison, it prints the appropriate message to the console.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/ScalerTopicsJava/Scanner/ScannerExample.java\":\"This file does not contain any classes or functions. Instead, it demonstrates the usage of the `Scanner` class from the `java.util` package to read integer and float values from the user input and print them to the console.\\n\\nThe file performs the following tasks:\\n\\n1. Imports the `Scanner` class from the `java.util` package.\\n2. Creates a `Scanner` object to read input from the system console.\\n3. Reads an integer value using `scanner.nextInt()` and stores it in the variable `a`.\\n4. Reads a float value using `scanner.nextFloat()` and stores it in the variable `b`.\\n5. Prints the values of `a` and `b` to the console.\\n6. Closes the `Scanner` object.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/GettingStarted/dataTypeConversions.java\":\"This file does not contain any classes or functions. Instead, it demonstrates data type conversions in Java.\\n\\nThe file performs the following operations:\\n1. Declares variables of different data types (float, double, byte, short, long).\\n2. Performs type casting and arithmetic operations on these variables.\\n3. Prints the results of the operations to the console.\\n\\nThe purpose of this file is to illustrate how data types can be converted and how different data types interact with each other in Java.\",\"/CombinationOfTablesJavaTask/src/models/Lab.java\":\"This file does not contain any classes, but it does have the following functions:\\n\\n`main`: This function is the entry point of the program, where it calls the `LabTable()` function and then prints the resulting data table.\\n\\n`LabTable`: This function creates a data table with a header row and four rows of data, representing different labs and their associated subjects.\\n\\n`printDataTable`: This function takes a list of lists of strings (representing a data table) and prints it to the console, with each cell separated by a tab character.\\n\\nIn summary, this file defines a simple data structure for a lab table and provides functions to create and print the data table.\",\"/Java Language Fundamentals/src/com/java/beginner/GettingStarted/ConditionalLogicAndBlockStatements/logicalOperations.java\":\"This file does not contain any classes or functions. Instead, it demonstrates the usage of logical operations in Java, such as the `AND` operator (`\\u0026`) and the negation operator (`!`).\\n\\nThe file performs the following operations:\\n\\n1. Checks if the value of `a` is greater than `b` and `b` is greater than `c`, and prints \\\"a is greater than b and c\\\" if the condition is true.\\n2.
